Jason Rogers wrote:
> But, you fail to consider that for some people (espec=
ially in 
> different
> cultures) the first way to help yourself may be to =
ask a 
> question.  

I can't get my brain around that statement.  How
can =
"asking a question" (which must include a 2nd 
party) be "helping yourself"=
 (which cannot include a 
2nd party)?

> You have also failed to consider t=
hat in some 
> countries Google is not necessarily a buzz-word, so the 
> q=
uestion may not be directed there.

That's true - I didn't really consider =
that.  Maybe
I'm being close-minded, but it's hard to fathom that 
a person=
 can find a website to sign up for an email 
list, but then be unable to do=
 a web search.  Heck,
the JUnit web page itself has two different web searc=
h 
fields on it - one for the web in general, and one 
to search for conten=
t of prior messages.  If this
list was about learning basic computing skill=
s, I
might believe what you wrote.  But everyone here is
in the software de=
velopment field.  How do you get 
to be a practicing software development p=
rofessional
(or student) in the 21st century without knowing how 
to do a w=
eb search?  (That question isn't totally 
rhetorical.  If there really is a=
 way, I'd love to 
hear about it.)


Simon Chappell wrote:
> That does take=
 a few minutes, but it's the nicest way to deal 
> with that sort of person=
 that I've seen. This list is very 
> friendly and helpful and populated by=
 some fine people, so 
> the last thing we want to do is to seem judgementa=
l or rude. 

Whoa!  I definitely didn't mean to imply that I
recommend bein=
g rude or judgmental to anyone.  I 
would hope that a separate beginner's l=
ist would 
continue to be just as polite and helpful as this
list is today.=


 
J.B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Todd, I appreciate your concern and have rais=
ed that myself, 
> in the past. 

Yes, I know we've discussed it here.

> I=
 would find it difficult to stay on this list 
> myself, if it weren't so l=
ow traffic. Also take into 
> consideration the number of posts we already =
reject, because 
> the questions are too basic. 

Wow, I did not realize th=
at there are posts getting
actively rejected!  If this is a moderated list,=

it seems like the moderators could easily reply
to the "whats junit" type =
of questions with a link 
to the FAQ and never pass those on to the rest of=
 
the group.

> If we don't encourage the 
> general public to post their q=
uestions, then who will we have 
> to discuss interesting topics with in a =
few years?

Perhaps I'm self-centered, because I expect others
to take the =
same general approach to learning a new
technology that I do, which is:  re=
ad what I can
about it until I get stuck, then read more from a
different a=
uthor, and if I'm still stuck, then ask
for help.  I believe that the peopl=
e who do NOT take
that approach aren't likely to be here to discuss
the int=
eresting topics in a few years.  I believe
that the people who ask the obvi=
ous FAQs get just
enough info to complete their homework assignment
or plac=
ate their boss or whatever, and then disappear 
and don't participate in fu=
rther discussions.  But
that's just a hunch.  Maybe I should do a random 
s=
urvey of "not-smart" questions from 2 years ago to 
see if those people are=
 the ones now actively con-
tributing to the discussion here.

> As a newbie user/lurker myself I don't recall reading the

ve made a note to look it up now...  

Just today I unsubscribed and then r=
esubscribed,
to confirm that the FAQ is automatically emailed 
to new membe=
rs.  I wonder if the auto mailer 
doesn't work for everyone.


Todd.
